column1: General anesthesia is treatment with certain medicines that puts you into a deep sleep so you do not feel pain during surgery.
General anesthesia is usually safe for healthy people.
- Several days to a week before surgery, you may be asked to stop taking drugs that make it hard for your blood to clot, such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), and warfarin (Coumadin).
Sometimes, nausea and vomiting can be treated with other medicines.
